item.title: Australian man reportedly killed while fighting in Ukraine
item.description: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade said it was seeking to confirm the reported death with authorities in Ukraine.

item.title: Dakar Rally 2026 nears as Aussie champ Daniel Sanders eyes 'back-to-back' wins
item.description: The 48th edition of the Dakar Rally kicks off this weekend in Saudi Arabia. Here's what to know about the gruelling motor race.

item.title: Power, pirate flags and political upheaval: How youth-led protests spread across borders
item.description: From Kathmandu to Manila, 2025 became a year when streets pushed back. Youth-led protests challenged corruption, demanding accountability.

item.title: Trump says US will intervene if Iran 'violently kills' protesters after reports of six deaths
item.description: Protests in Iran that started over high rates of inflation and a fall in the currency have led to several deaths, Iranian media reports say.

item.title: 'I put myself out there': Khawaja calls stumps on international career with message to critics
item.description: Khawaja said he'll forever carry the memories, friendships and "lessons that shaped me".

item.description: A five minute bulletin for English language learners

item.title: Why Usman Khawaja's influence went far beyond the cricket pitch
item.description: From advocating for representation to speaking out on Gaza, Usman Khawaja's influence reaches well beyond the boundary — with many Australians viewing him as "a symbol of resilience and inclusion".

item.title: The opposition leader in exile who once ran against Europe's longest-reigning autocrat
item.description: Meet the woman sentenced to 15 years in prison in her home country who Australian leaders call "a fearless advocate for democracy and justice".

item.title: As calls grow for a Bondi royal commission, do Albanese's arguments stand up?
item.description: The prime minister has said an intelligence review is a faster and more appropriate tool to get answers on the Bondi terror attack.

item.title: Iranian-Australians speak about growing protests while expert highlights two 'wildcards'
item.description: At least eight protesters have been killed, and several have been arrested, according to an Iranian human rights organisation.

item.title: Worried about AI taking your job? Experts say that's only half the story
item.description: Experts say AI won't just replace jobs — it could spark new industries and opportunities Australians can't yet imagine.

item.title: 'It's important because we're equal': The push to make safe relationships more accessible
item.description: A new online learning module is aiming to provide education and support around intimacy rights for people with disability.

item.title: Laura’s plant-based milk is changing the lives of some of the world’s poorest women
item.description: Australia’s non-dairy milk market is worth more than $600 million annually and is growing rapidly. One plant-based milk business run by an Australian entrepreneur also supports some of the world’s poorest women.

item.title: 'Going to get the oil flowing': Donald Trump wants Venezuela's oil. But is it legal?
item.description: The US government has not provided any details on how the US is going to take control of Venezuelan oil, but experts warn it will take years.

item.title: 'We have become stronger': How squash is transforming the lives of Syrian refugee girls
item.description: In Jordan, an unlikely education program is using squash to keep refugee girls in school and open doors once thought impossible.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Dr Patsie Frawley on promoting intimacy rights for people with disabilities
item.description: Associate Professor Patsie Frawley researches sexuality rights as well as violence and abuse prevention in the lives of people with disabilities.

item.title: Farah escaped turmoil in Iran. Now her work carries Melbourne every day
item.description: From wear and tear to fresh starts, Melbourne tram seats carry an untold story about work, opportunity and belonging in the city.

item.title: Joy and insecurity: Venezuelan Australians like Maria are conflicted on US strikes
item.description: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade says it's checking to determine whether any Australians were affected by the US attacks on Venezuela.

item.title: Why has China introduced new tariffs on Australian beef?
item.description: An expert says the impact of China's new tariff is "hard to assess", but Australian exporters may have found their way out.

item.title: Venezuelans in Australia respond as events unfold
item.description: Events in Venezuela have stirred emotion among the Latin American diaspora in Australia. In Sydney and Melbourne, Venezuelans are gathering in streets and community spaces as developments unfold.

item.title: What Venezuela means for petrol prices and oil
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Saul Kavonic from MST Marquee to find out what the developments in Venezuela means for oil and petrol prices; plus Armina Rosenberg from Minatour Capital takes a look at the key sharemarket investment themes for 2026.

item.title: The questions still hanging over Trump's plan to 'run' Venezuela
item.description: Donald Trump is insisting the United States is in charge of Venezuela and has not ruled out putting "boots on the ground".

item.title: Three-day childcare subsidy now in place - but will it help families?
item.description: Parents sending children to childcare are now guaranteed a 90 per cent subsidy for three days a week, without completing any eligibility test. The subsidy will cost around $430 million over the next four years but the government says hundreds of thousands of families are set to benefit.

item.title: 'Absolutely terrified': How Judi's daunting travel moment reshaped her life
item.description: A mix of grief, fear and empowerment is driving more widowed women to travel alone. Experts say the shift speaks to how women navigate life after loss.

item.title: 'I don't want to go back': The Australians reinventing themselves in midlife
item.description: Most of us will reassess our purpose in midlife and many of us will completely switch careers — although it doesn't always work out.

item.title: Police investigate antisemitism link to man arrested over alleged arson attack in Melbourne
item.description: A 47-year-old man is in custody awaiting an interview with investigators.

item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Chris Brycki from Stockspot about the Dow Jones Index overnight record and takes a closer look at the joint takeover bid for Bluescope Steel.

item.title: Nearly seven million Australians at risk from urban fires, new report warns
item.description: Almost seven million people living on the expanding fringes of Australia's capital cities are at risk from urban fires similar to those seen in Los Angeles last year. The warning, by former Australian fire chiefs and the Climate Council comes as the country is set to swelter in one of the most significant heatwaves of recent years.

item.title: Protesters banned from Sydney streets for another two weeks under controversial restrictions
item.description: The controversial protest ban can be extended every fortnight for up to three months.

item.title: The reality virtually no Aussie can escape when a heatwave hits
item.description: Everyone in heatwave-affected areas is at risk — even "healthy, fit young people". Here's how extreme heat affects your body and how to stay safe.

item.title: 'We bitterly regret this': Swiss authorities' admission about bar where 40 died in NYE fire
item.description: Regular fire safety inspections had not been carried out at the bar where a deadly fire broke out on New Year's Eve, authorities have said.

item.title: Zelenskyy praises European, US moves towards legally binding security guarantees for Ukraine
item.description: Discussions on security guarantees for Ukraine have advanced among Western allies, but Russia has given no public sign it would accept the arrangements.

item.title: Trump says Venezuelan oil to be shipped to US ports as 'war crime' attack condemned
item.description: The US president said the oil "will be taken by storage ships, and brought directly to unloading docks in the United States".

item.title: Why the latest inflation dip 'keeps alive' interest rate hike expectations
item.description: Headline inflation has come in lower than expected. But will that mean an interest rate reprieve? Not necessarily, economists say.

item.description: Trump's attention is again on Greenland — but why? Here's what to know, as allies raise alarm and talks are set for next week.

item.title: What is diet stacking and are you doing it?
item.description: Fodmap, high protein, gluten-free, lowfat, clean eating - so many diets, so much conflicting advice. Australian experts are warning that following multiple diets at the same time could have unexpected consequences.

item.title: Australia's trees are dying faster than they're being replaced
item.description: A new study has found trees across Australia are dying at a faster rate than new ones are growing, a trend that is contributing to an increase in carbon emissions. The research, led by Western Sydney University and published in the Nature Plants journal, has found trees in all types of ecosystems - from tropical rainforests to eucalypt forests - are thinning as the climate warms.

item.title: Is easing inflation enough to stop a February interest rate rise?
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks to Pradeep Philip, from Deloitte Access Economics, and Alice Shen, CFA from VanEck, about the latest inflation result and the day's sharemarket moves.

item.description: If you want to get your year started on the right financial footing, here are 10 ways to save money.

item.title: Greenland says it will join talks with US and Denmark amid Trump acquisition push
item.description: Greenland has repeatedly stated it does not wish to be part of the US, which, under Donald Trump, has expressed interest in acquiring the Danish territory.

item.title: Woman fatally shot by ICE in Minneapolis identified, officials spar over cause of shooting
item.description: The US government said the agent fired in self-defence, while the local mayor said video of the incident contradicted that narrative.

item.description: DFAT says a violent crackdown on protests in Iran has left many "injured, killed or detained", and is urging Australians to depart the country.

item.description: The US will withdraw from the treaty underpinning all major international climate agreements and the UN climate science body, according to a White House memo.

item.description: President Maduro snatched from his bed, Trump’s grab for Greenland unifies Europe. Plus, nationwide protests rattle the Iranian regime, and China’s stiff rise in the cost of condoms.

item.description: The US has seized a Russian-flagged oil tanker in the Atlantic, after tracking it for weeks and calling in the assistance of the UK.

item.description: In Australia, the only severe weather events that receive formal names are tropical cyclones. Could there be benefits to naming all of our extreme weather?

item.description: Local and federal authorities continue to clash and protesters have taken to the streets after the fatal shooting of a woman in the US city of Minneapolis.

item.description: The prisoner releases appear to be a concession to the US after its ouster of leader Nicolás Maduro.

item.description: Adelaide Writer's Week has come under pressure from prominent writers from its decision to drop a Palestinian author after the Bondi attack.

item.description: Deadly protests in Iran have spread to more provinces presenting a new challenge for the country's leadership. It is the biggest wave of protests since the nationwide demonstrations in 2022, sparked by the death in custody of Mahsa Amini.

item.description: The US homeland security department confirmed that a border patrol agent had fired shots.

item.description: Tensions between Minnesota and federal officials have deepened over a United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement officer's fatal shooting of a woman in the city of Minneapolis. item.description: Lena was supposed to attend the Hannukah by the Sea event in Bondi where her 10-year-old granddaughter Matilda was killed.

item.description: Cost of living pressures mean both parents often need to work and there's one flexible arrangement that has become crucial to the functioning of households.

item.description: Hundreds of "ICE Out" rallies are planned across the US amid growing outrage after an immigration officer shot and killed a woman behind the wheel of her car.

item.description: The Victorian bushfires have resulted in significant losses of livestock, cropping land and vineyards as well damage to critical infrastructure, with many fires still burning

item.description: Wallabies are running wild on the Isle of Man, and these small creatures are stirring a big debate among locals: should they be kept or culled?

item.description: The 'Super-K' flu — otherwise known as the subclade-K variant — is spreading around the globe, including Australia.

item.title: Victoria bushfires: Farmer reportedly identified as man killed in Longwood blaze
item.description: The deceased person is yet to be formally identified, however several media outlets identified him as cattle farmer Maxwell Hobson.

item.title: No, you can't transfer your prize, Nobel body says amid Machado's Trump suggestion
item.description: The organisation that oversees the Nobel Peace Prize has thrown cold water on talk of the Venezuelan opposition leader giving her award to Donald Trump.

item.title: Board members, chair quit from Adelaide Festival as fallout from dropped author grows
item.description: SBS News can confirm three board members have now resigned from the Adelaide Festival, amid growing controversy over a decision to drop a Palestinian Australian author and academic.

item.title: I'm a pet doula. I have a grief plan in place for when my own dogs die
item.description: Dr Anupam Sharma doesn't want a partner or children. Pets are her life, and as a veterinarian and veterinary doula, she prepares us for life without them.

item.description: A new report shows which areas of Australia will record the biggest population increases in the years ahead.

item.description: Protests have swelled in recent days despite an internet blackout that has lasted more than 60 hours, according to monitor Netblocks.

item.title: Nationwide protests against ICE sweep across United States
item.description: At least 29 people have been arrested in Minneapolis during ongoing protests over the fatal shooting of a US citizen by an Immigration and Customs Enforcement agent. The killing of Renee Good has sparked demonstrations across the country, while further confrontations with ICE agents have been filmed.

item.title: Cuba defiant after Trump says to 'make a deal, before it is too late'
item.description: Donald Trump has warned Cuba will no longer receive Venezuelan oil or funds, increasing US pressure on the island nation.

item.title: 'Big bill' for taxpayers but cheaper for patients: Wegovy to be subsidised, says minister
item.description: It's going to cost taxpayers a lot of money — but the federal government says subsidising weight loss drug Wegovy is an equity issue, not just a health issue.

item.title: Iran's anti-government protests continue to spread
item.description: Anti-government protests in Iran have now entered a third week. Human rights groups say more than 490 protesters and 48 security personnel have already been killed since the demonstrations began. Iranian authorities have vowed to toughen their response to demonstrators further, accusing the United States and Israel of trying to escalate unrest.

item.title: 'Factories of hate': New laws to crack down on radical preachers
item.description: The new powers will shut down premises that are "operating unlawfully and spreading division".

item.description: Donald Trump has consistently pressured Jerome Powell and the central bank to move faster in lowering interest rates.

item.title: PM recalls parliament in bid to fast-track hate speech laws and gun reform
item.description: There will also be a condolence motion to "unequivocally condemn" the Bondi terror attack, the prime minister said.

item.title: Critical mission: why rare earths and minerals are a new priority for Australia
item.description: As the world's population becomes increasingly reliant on critical minerals to make technology from smart phones to car parts and even weapons, the resource has become a matter of national security. The Australian Government, announcing that it will prioritise several key critical minerals in the nation's 1.2 billion dollar strategic reserve.

item.title: Australian Open 2026: Your guide to this year's tournament
item.description: One of the world's biggest tennis tournaments is back for another year. Here's what you need to know.

item.title: Bushfires devastate Victorian communities
item.description: Cooler conditions are helping fire crews in Victoria contain the raging bushfires which have devastated regional communities around the state for the past six days. But with many blazes still out of control, those communities now face an overwhelming recovery and uncertain future.

item.title: Jerome Powell facing criminal probe and implications for markets
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Kyle Rodda from capital.com about the day's market action including implications of the US Adminstration's threat to lob criminal charges against Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell as he stands firm on interest rate policy.

item.title: Australian Open gets underway: what to know about this year’s tournament
item.description: One of the world's biggest tennis tournaments is back for another year as the Australian Open gets underway in Melbourne. Here's a breakdown of some of the details of the Australian Grand Slam as well as some key names to watch out for.

item.title: Ardern withdraws from Writers' Week; Adelaide Festival board faces fresh questions
item.description: Former NZ prime minister pulls out of event. Meanwhile, a past Writers' Week director has questioned the Adelaide Festival board's viability after resignations.

item.description: Victorian bushfires continue to burn, with one carer warning the real toll on wildlife may only emerge in the weeks ahead.

item.description: The Bureau of Meteorology has issued a severe weather warning for much of the central coast and Capricornia districts.

item.description: Randa Abdel-Fattah, the author whose removal from Writers' Week has sparked a backlash, said Adler's resignation is "a tragedy".

item.description: Adelaide United has said it's "extremely disappointed" by allegations that homophobia led to Josh Cavallo's departure from the A-League Men club.

item.title: Autism Barbie is unboxed, to mixed reaction from advocates
item.description: Autism advocates have had mixed reactions to the release of an autism Barbie, designed to increase awareness and acceptance of neurodiversity in children, particularly girls. American toymaker Mattel announced the new doll this week, including special features to accomodate the traits and behaviours associated with autism.

item.description: Randa Abdel-Fattah has rejected the Adelaide Festival board's apology for removing her from their line-up, calling it 'disingenuous'.

item.title: Behind the stoush: Jerome Powell alleges 'intimidation', as Trump says he's 'not very good'
item.description: The long-standing feud between Donald Trump and the head of America's central bank has just escalated — because of renovations.

item.title: 'I see nightmares': Iran's move that's created a 'graveyard of the living' amid protests
item.description: Amid more than two weeks of protests in Iran, members of the Iranian diaspora in Australia have expressed concern for their loved ones.

item.title: Kevin Rudd announces resignation as Australia's ambassador to the United States
item.description: Kevin Rudd will end his tenure as Australia's ambassador to the US a year early, to take up a role in international policy and research. It follows a tumultuous period for the former Labor prime minister under the Trump administration and marks the end of a long and sometimes controversial public life.

item.title: Renowned author accused of engaging with paedophiles, sharing child abuse material
item.description: Craig Silvey has been charged with possessing and distributing child exploitation material between 7 and 9 of January.

item.title: Renowned author accused of engaging with paedophiles, sharing child abuse material
item.description: Craig Silvey has been charged with possessing and distributing child exploitation material between 7 and 9 of January.

item.title: Newly unveiled hate crime laws ignite political debate
item.description: People who join or support government designated hate groups face 15 years jail under new legislation in the wake of the Bondi terrorist attack. MPs today scrambling to get across the detail of the laws, to be voted in just a week, with concerns already around some religious freedom exemptions.

item.title: Major bank issues warning on AI Deepfake scams
item.description: New research suggests Australians are dangerously overconfident about detecting AI deepfake scams, even as the technology becomes harder to spot. Experts warn scammers hijack trust and instinct, and are calling on people to pause, verify and reject suspicious messages.

item.title: Global markets and precious metals hit record high despite Powell investigation
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Kai Chen from MPC Markets about why US, Japanese and German markets are hitting record highs despite the US Administration's investigation into Jerome Powell, plus Matthew Hassan from Westpac on consumer sentiment.

item.title: Neo-Nazi groups say they will disband ahead of introduction of proposed hate speech laws
item.description: Organisers of the National Socialist Network and affiliated groups have said the organisations will be shut down to avoid members being prosecuted.

item.title: The secret my dad kept was meant to protect me — it still broke my heart
item.description: Irene was just a few weeks from giving birth when she uncovered a timely secret about her dad, who lived on the other side of the world.

item.title: 'Unsafe' and 'unfairly scrutinised': How the Bondi terror attack changed Australia
item.description: The massacre during a Jewish Hanukkah festival — and its aftermath — have made indelible impacts on the country.

item.title: Donald Trump tells Iranians to keep protesting, says 'help is on its way'
item.description: An Iranian official confirmed that around 2,000 people had been killed in the protests, the first time authorities have given an overall death toll.

item.title: 'We choose Denmark' over the US, Greenland's PM says ahead of White House talks
item.description: Senior Danish and Greenlandic officials are preparing for White House talks on Arctic security and sovereignty.

item.title: Parents 'under pressure': The cost of educating children in Australia revealed
item.description: Nearly half of the parents surveyed said they are considering having fewer children because of the cost of raising and educating them.

item.title: Michele Bullock joins world central bank chiefs declaring 'full solidarity' with Jerome Powell
item.description: Donald Trump has, for months, been piling pressure on Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell to lower rates faster, arguing it would support a weakening US economy.

item.description: Premier unaware whether a concerns notice from Randa Abdel-Fattah has been received, after remarks she calls a "vicious personal assault".

item.title: 'Fundamentally different': Jewish group joins push to split up hate crime bill
item.description: There are concerns that the scope of the hate speech laws, which include gun reform and migration changes, "risks" its passage.

item.title: Greenland chooses Denmark as Trump steps up the rhetoric
item.description: United States President Donald Trump is escalating his push for U.S. control of Greenland, declaring the United States will take the Arctic territory “one way or another” and warning that Russian and Chinese forces are operating in the region. Arctic and security experts say those claims are overstated, as Denmark and Greenland firmly reject any U.S. takeover. NATO is closely monitoring the dispute, amid concerns the escalating rhetoric could strain or fracture the alliance.

item.title: Author threatens to sue South Australia's premier for defamation | SBS News in Easy English 14 January 2026
item.description: A daily news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Iran's diaspora desperate to hear word from family as communications blackout persists
item.description: Iran’s nationwide communications blackout has entered its second week, severely limiting access to real-time information about the deadly crackdown on anti-government protesters. Iranian authorities have warned that those taking part in the protests could face the death penalty, as reports suggest the death toll has risen to around 2,000. Meanwhile, U.S. President Donald Trump has urged Iranians to continue protesting against the country’s leadership, telling demonstrators that “help is on its way.”

item.title: Labor mulls extending hate speech laws to include LGBTIQ+ Australians and others
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has signalled this could occur if the current bill becomes law.

item.title: Global central bankers show support for US Fed Chair Jerome Powell
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Hebe Chen from Vantage Australia about the day's sharemarket action including the significance of a joint statement released by a dozen global central bankers, including the RBA's Michele Bullock, supporting US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, who is under investigation by the US administration.

item.title: Bondi attack prompts possible 15-year jail terms for hate group members
item.description: People who join or support government-designated hate groups will face 15 years jail, under new legislation in response to the Bondi terror attack. Some Coalition MPs have already voiced concern about the laws' impact on freedom of speech - while one prominent extremist group has announced it will disband.

item.title: Trump's Iran endgame: What 'winning' could look like
item.description: The US president says he wants to "win" in Iran. As rhetoric escalates, experts question what that means — and whether military action looms.

item.title: Bushfire property losses top 700 as Victoria premier defends fleeing angry locals
item.description: Property losses are mounting as fire authorities and residents regain access to communities after a state bushfire crisis.

item.title: What would you do if you lost your job? Acclaimed director's new film has a dark answer
item.description: When your job defines you, losing it can have deadly consequences. At least that's the case in Park Chan-wook's thriller No Other Choice.

item.title: Causing cancer and disrupting hormones? The dangerous myths online about sunscreen
item.description: Online fears about sunscreen are popping up, but the science remains unchanged: it’s safe and protective. Here's what we know.

item.title: Debate continues overdraft hate speech laws | Morning News Bulletin 15 January 2026

item.description: The announcement follows Denmark's and Greenland's foreign ministers holding high-stakes talks with US vice president JD Vance.

item.description: Donald Trump has openly threatened to intervene in Iran for days, without giving specifics.

item.description: A "sustained period of wet weather" will help ease the immediate bushfire danger, but also raises the risk of flash flooding.

item.title: Adelaide Festival retracts statement on Randa Abdel-Fattah, invites her to next writers' week
item.description: The Palestinian Australian author said she is considering the invitation to next year's event, after organisers said they apologised "unreservedly".

item.title: Warnings for Australian travellers to the Middle East, as Iran reopens airspace
item.description: Travellers to countries surrounding Iran have been warned about the risk of "regional conflict, missiles and drones".

item.title: Trade off: major divisions ahead of the signing of the historic Mercosur trade deal
item.description: It's being heralded as one of the biggest trade deals in history, with the EU and some Latin American nations poised to sign the Mercosur Agreement this weekend. Designed in part to reduce reliance on the United States and China and find new growth markets, the deal has attracted strong opposition from some European countries and industries.

item.title: Faith groups call for hate speech reforms to be pushed back | Midday News Bulletin 15 January 2026
item.description: Faith groups call for hate speech reforms to be pushed back; The US to suspend immigration visa applications from 75 countries; And in sport, Australia's Willie Peters tipped to become England's new national rugby league coach.

item.title: Labor's hate speech laws on the brink as Coalition raises doubts and Greens reject plan
item.description: With the Coalition and Greens taking a swipe at the bill, questions exist over how the government could pass hate speech reform.

item.title: US stops processing immigrant visa applications from 75 countries | SBS News In Easy English 15 January 2026
item.description: A daily 5 minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Climate report warns of increasingly extreme weather
item.description: The European Union's latest annual climate report reveals last year was the world's third-hottest on record. The report also finds the global three-year average has warmed by more than 1.5 degrees Celsius for the first time, a threshold scientists warn dramatically increases the risk of extreme weather events. Climate experts say while the findings are troubling, China and India have made notable improvements in reducing emissions.

item.title: The plan to tackle Australia's drowning crisis
item.description: Since the start of summer, 33 people have lost their lives to drowning in Australia. With drowning trending upwards since the COVID-19 Pandemic, the Australian Water Safety Council has released a new Australian Water Safety Strategy 2030, strengthening national efforts to reduce drowning deaths by 50 per cent by the end of the decade.

item.title: PM announces $26 million in support for flood-affected Queenslanders | Evening News Bulletin 15 January 2026
item.description: Hate speech laws in jeopardy as Greens and Coalition signal their opposition; The PM announces $26 million in additional support for flood-affected Queenslanders; And in football, Moroccans celebrate making it to the grand final of the African Cup of Nations.

item.title: Iran’s brutal crackdown, Trump greases oil execs for Venezuela & Indonesia’s onion repeal
item.description: Can the economy-driven protests in Iran bring down the regime? Plus, the Venezuelan oil games continue as President Trump declares his global power answers to just one thing (hint: it’s not the UN or God), and why illegal importers are dicing with danger in Indonesia.

item.title: 'Fighter's chance': Australian woman to set sail for Gaza on Global Sumud flotilla again
item.description: Juliet Lamont hopes to bring aid into Gaza by sea. The last time she tried, she was detained by Israel.

item.title: BHP challenging for CBA's crown & why US rates may not fall
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Chris Weston from Pepperstone as BHP edges closer to becoming Australia's largest listed company and finds out why he thinks US interest rates may not fall this year.

item.title: 'Descended into madness': A rare message from inside Iran lays bare an activist's fear
item.description: SBS News has spoken to a protester in Iran, describing authorities shooting at civilians amid the country's internet blackout.

item.title: 'Huge achievement': Labor hails wave of under-16 social media account deletions, restrictions
item.description: While the government has welcomed the new data, an expert cautions that it's unclear how many under-16s have stopped using social media.

item.title: Neo-Nazi groups say they're disbanding but this may not be their end, experts say
item.description: Proposed hate laws may disrupt neo-Nazi groups, but experts warn the threat could persist even if the legislation passes.

item.title: Trump says Iran protests easing but won't rule out military strikes
item.description: US President Donald Trump says Iran's crackdown on protests appears to be easing, amid reports a detained protester will avoid the death penalty.

item.title: ISS astronauts return to Earth in NASA's first medical evacuation
item.description: The four-person crew safely splashed down off California a few weeks ahead of their scheduled return due to an unspecified health emergency.

item.title: 'Very generous of her': Wong praises Machado for gifting Nobel prize to Trump
item.description: The foreign minister made the comments after she was asked if the US was creating a world order in which "might was right".

item.title: The Coalition accused of hypocrisy over hate law changes | Morning News Bulletin 16 January 2026
item.description: The Coalition accused of hypocrisy over its opposition to the government's planned hate law changes; A violent crackdown in Uganda as voting begins in the presidential election; A nightmare Australian Open draw for Alex de Minaur.

item.title: Antidepressants didn't work for Alexis — she's not alone
item.description: A landmark Australian study has found people living with atypical depression are less likely to respond to medication.

item.title: Venezuela's opposition leader meets Donald Trump in the White House | Midday News Bulletin 16 January 2026
item.description: Venezuela's opposition leader meets Donald Trump in the White House; The government confident new figures show social media ban reforms are working; And in sport, Australian para skiier Josh Hanlon claims a podium finish.

item.title: European troops arrive in Greenland as Trump holds firm on acquisition
item.description: Greenland is rapidly becoming a geopolitical flashpoint. European troops are arriving on the island, Denmark is pushing for a stronger NATO presence, and the Trump administration insisting it still wants the United States to acquire Greenland.

item.title: 'It feels like fascism': Minnesota residents say they won't be bullied by President Trump
item.description: US President Donald Trump has threatened to invoke the Insurrection Act and deploy troops to quell protests against Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers in Minneapolis. Tensions have flared in the city after a federal officer shot and wounded a Venezuelan man during an attempted arrest.

item.title: ICE shootings and Trump's threat to 'insurrectionists': Unrest in Minnesota, explained
item.description: Trump threatens to deploy troops to Minnesota as protests erupt over federal immigration operations and a second officer-involved shooting.

item.title: President Trump meets with Venezuelan opposition leader | SBS News In Easy English 16 January 2026
item.description: A daily 5 minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Why are women worried about their financial future?
item.description: There's a stark gender divide in retirement confidence, with new research from AMP revealing only two in five Australian women feel secure about their financial future, compared to three in five men. The gap is widest among single and divorced women in their 40s, who are often juggling work, children and ageing parents. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with AMP’s Director of Growth and Customer Solutions, Julie Slapp.

item.title: One month on, how is the teen social media ban working?
item.description: New figures reveal more than 4.7 million social media accounts were deactivated, removed or restricted, when Australia's world-first age restrictions took effect in December. The reforms are the subject of much scrutiny around the world, as a number of nations move to address a new threat to social media users in the past week.

item.title: INTERVIEW: How is the social media ban working and is it an effective measure?
item.description: It's been just over a month since the government enacted its world-first social media ban for those aged under 16 years old. The government says they have deactivated, removed or restricted 4.7 million accounts so far. But what does this figure mean, and is an outright ban the most effective method for mitigating young people's exposure to harmful content online? In this episode of Weekend One on One Catriona Stirrat speaks to Nicholas Carah - Director of the Center for Digital Cultures and Societies at the University of Queensland.

item.title: Faith leaders call for pause in hate speech laws | Evening News Bulletin 16 January 2026
item.description: Faith leaders warn that hate speech laws may infringe on religious freedoms; Foreign Minister Penny Wong urges Australians to leave Iran immediately if possible; And in tennis, defending champion Jannik Sinner confident about his Australian Open chances.

item.title: 'Risk of unintended consequences': Faith leaders call for pause in hate speech laws
item.description: Religious leaders have united across faiths to urge the prime minister to go back to the drawing board on contentious hate speech reforms.

item.title: ASX hits 11 week high
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Isaac Poole from Oreana Private Wealth as the Australian sharemarket hits a record high, despite a growing divergence of opnion on the direction of US interest rates.

item.title: 'Someone out there cares': When fires raged, a Melbourne baker opened his doors
item.description: As fires displace thousands in Victoria, a Melbourne baker draws on his refugee past to help evacuees and emergency service volunteers.

item.title: Coroner refers exploited migrant worker's death to federal police
item.description: The death of a migrant worker who was exploited and fearful of his visa sponsor has prompted calls for the creation of an anti-slavery hotline.

item.title: How did Australia's 'most liveable' capital city become the most affordable for renting a house?
item.description: Only one capital city in Australia has seen the cost of renting a house go down over the last 12 months.

item.title: Asian-Inspired coffees gain ground in Australia
item.description: Australia is known worldwide for its strong coffee culture. But across major cities, new styles blending Asian flavours with more familiar brews are quietly reshaping café menus.

item.title: An inquiry underway into fatal shooting of a man by NSW Police | Morning News Bulletin 17 January 2026
item.description: An inquiry underway into the fatal shooting of a man by New South Wales Police; Kurdish separatists based in Iraq launch an attack on Iran; World-number-one Aryna Sabalenka to push for a third Australian Open title.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Loneliness - the hidden health danger
item.description: A lot of people already identify or know the problems from smoking and what it can do for your health, but not a lot of people understand that loneliness or social isolation carries around the same health risks of smoking up to 15 cigarettes a day. Tyler Prochnow is an assistant professor at Texas A&M at their School of Public Health and an expert in social connectedness, physical activity and mental health.

item.title: Donald Trump threatens tariffs on countries that don't support Greenland takeover plan
item.description: Large demonstrations are planned across Denmark and Greenland this weekend to protest against Trump's plan.

item.title: Donald Trump appoints Tony Blair, Marco Rubio and more to Gaza 'board of peace'
item.description: The group will supervise the temporary governance of Gaza, under a US plan.

item.title: Wet weekend ahead for NSW and NT as clean-up underway in parts of Victoria
item.description: Rain could lead to flash flooding in parts of Sydney, with heavy rainfall in the NT's Top End also expected.

item.title: She's a 'crazy pigeon lady'. He wants to revive a dying sport. This bird is their obsession
item.description: Your perception of pigeons is wrong, these Australians say. Their lives revolve around them — but their worlds couldn't be more different.

item.title: Trump has been gifted a Nobel Peace Prize. Can they actually be given away?
item.description: The Norwegian Nobel Committee released a pointed statement after María Corina Machado gave her peace prize medal to Donald Trump.

item.title: Victorian authorities defend flash flood alerts | Midday News Bulletin 17 January 2026
item.description: Authorities defend weather warnings after flash flooding on Victoria's Great Ocean Road; Donald Trump threatens more tariffs in his quest for Greenland; A Matildas veteran suffers a potentially career-ending injury.

item.title: Government to separate gun laws, drop racial vilification from sweeping reform bill
item.description: It comes after the Greens announced it would back the gun law reforms but refused to support the bill's other proposals.

item.title: How much for a coffee? New drinks are pushing prices to $8 or more
item.description: Classic coffee styles continue to dominate sales, but a new trend reflects a wider shift in tastes shaped by Australia's increasingly diverse population.

item.title: Albanese splits hate speech and gun reform bill in two | Evening News Bulletin 17 January 2026
item.description: The PM says the hate speech and gun reform bill is to be split before it's introduced to the Parliament on Tuesday, Greenland's Indigenous population says it does not want to be colonised a second time, The Special Ks set to take the court together for the mens doubles at the Australian Open.

item.title: US justice department investigating Minnesota governor for alleged ICE obstruction
item.description: Minnesota governor Tim Walz said the justice ‌system was being weaponised to intimidate Donald Trump's perceived political enemies.

item.title: Government splits hate speech and gun laws in bid to save Bondi reforms
item.description: The Albanese government has amended its proposed response to the Bondi Beach shootings, splitting its wide-ranging hate speech and gun reform package in two in a bid to secure passage through Parliament. Facing resistance from both the Coalition and the Greens over the breadth and rushed nature of the laws, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has made changes in hopes of receiving support from both political groups to pass each set of reforms.

item.title: Woman killed by falling tree branch in NSW as storms force evacuations in Sydney
item.description: Thunderstorms and heavy rain have swept across the state,

item.title: Darren lengthened his legs to be taller. Now he walks with a limp
item.description: More people than ever before are making themselves taller with surgery. But while this can improve lives, some are left with long-term problems.

item.title: The EU signs trade deal with the Mercosur group | Morning News Bulletin 18 January 2026
item.description: The EU signs a massive trade deal with the Mercosur group of South American countries; Labor works to secure support after splitting hate speech and gun reform into separate bills; Play begins at Melbourne Park for the 2026 Australian Open.

item.title: Australia's 'most liveable' city is now the cheapest to rent houses
item.description: The housing crisis has seen people finding it increasingly hard to rent or buy a house in Australia's capital cities. But while most of the country has seen prices going up there's one place where prices have gone down - and that's Melbourne, where rental prices have gone down almost two percent year on year. SBS's Cameron Carr spoke to Dr Nicola Powell from Domain, to find out what's driving down prices.

item.title: 'Full solidarity': European countries react after Trump's tariff announcement over Greenland
item.description: The countries named by Trump have backed Denmark, warning that the US' plans could collapse the NATO military alliance.

item.title: From lifeline to 'existential crisis': The high human cost of Victoria's public housing overhaul
item.description: In the middle of a housing and cost-of-living crisis, the Victorian government is in the process of demolishing all 44 of Melbourne's public housing towers. Despite significant pushback and a parliamentary inquiry calling for an immediate halt to works, the Victorian government is pushing ahead with the plans.

item.title: Iran's leader says 'several thousand' killed during anti-regime protests
item.description: Human rights groups say more than 3,000 people have been killed and more than 20,000 arrested during the demonstratoins.

item.title: Thinking of changing your career this year? Consider these five steps before you do
item.description: Between a shrinking job market, redundancies, and the threat of AI, changing careers in 2026 is different from how it used to be.

item.title: Evacuations on Sydney's northern beaches amid flash flooding concerns | Midday News Bulletin 18 January 2026
item.description: Residents evacuated on Sydney's northern beaches amid flash flooding concerns; Palestinians in Gaza voice concern as the US unveils a temporary 'Board of Peace'; In snowboarding, Scotty James surges into Olympic contention after a dominant win at the final World Cup halfpipe event.

item.title: 'Worrying moment': Can Trump use tariffs to force a Greenland deal under international law?
item.description: In his bid to control the autonomous Danish territory, Trump has vowed to hit European allies with additional levies.

item.title: Man arrested over pipe bomb discovery in Canberra
Man arrested over pipe bombs found in Canberra | Evening News Bulletin 18 January 2026
item.description: A man arrested over the discovery of pipe bombs in Canberra last week; Greenlanders take to the streets to protest Donald Trump; Tahlia Gibson the first local player through to the Australian Open's second round.

item.title: South Australian premier's push for Adelaide Festival to drop Abdel-Fattah revealed in letter
item.description: A newly published letter shows how the South Australian premier argued for Randa Abdel-Fattah to be dropped from Adelaide Writers' Week.

item.title: Motive for Canberra pipe bombs still unknown, police say, after arresting 41-year-old
item.description: Police believe the man acted alone and, while they haven't identified any motivation, "are confident it's not related to terrorism".

item.title: Motive for Canberra pipe bombs still unknown, police say, after arresting 41-year-old
item.description: Police believe the man acted alone and, while they haven't identified any motivation, "are confident it's not related to terrorism".

item.title: Protesters vow to return on 26 January after deaths in custody demonstration dispersed
item.description: In the lead-up to the event, demonstrators said they were planning to march in defiance of NSW's controversial new protest laws.
